info.name: NGSI-LD Test Suite Localhost
info.description: Sample operations to help understand the NGSI-LD API.

item.name: Setting up context internally (Optional)

request.description: This request represents another way to add context files to the server. In this example, we use an existing context file (in .jsonld) instead of providing a JSON payload with @context.

item.name: (1a) Adding a context, returns link to context file in header

request.description:
This request represents one of the ways to add a context file to the context broker. After adding it, the broker returns the link to the context file in the header.

Note that the link might be broken depending on the deployment method. This example should return a link similar to this:

> http://orion:1026/ngsi-ld/v1/jsonldContexts/c92fea6c-e1dd-11ee-9208-0242ac1a0005 
  

Change "orion:1026" to "{{gateway}}/api/broker" and you should be able to access the context file, hosted on Orion
Retrieve links to all context files in the context broker.
Delete a particular context file from the context broker.

item.description:
To better utilize the NGSI-LD API, we first have to upload our own context file. These context files help us to define shared vocabulary in our data model. Hence, we map terms we use in entity creation to their actual meanings in an ontology.

This ensures that when data is exchanged between different systems, the meaning of these terms is understood consistently by all parties.

NOTE: We are using our own context server hosted at [http://34.126.76.13](http://34.126.76.13) for the rest of the tutorial.

### Adapted from:

[https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/working-with-@context.html](https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/working-with-%40context.html)

item.name: Creating a Room entity
Room that directly get's data from a temperature sensor

request.description: Create Room that directly get's data from a temperature sensor, without temperature sensor entity
View the created entities (which are of type Room)

This request adds a Room entity using a payload in the key-value format.

Note that all attributes of an entity will default to being of type "Property" unless explicitly stated.

item.name: Deleting an entity - Room that directly gets data from sensor

request.description: Delete a created entity by specifying the id
This request adds a Room entity using a payload in the normalized-json format. This is the most explicit way of creating an entity, through explicitly stating the type of each attribute.
Delete a created entity by specifying the id

item.description:
To start off, we first create a Room entity. In this example, a Room entity is an enclosed space that sensors, robots or cameras can be located in.

Each entity has a unique ID. Hence, its not possible to create two entities with the same ID, even with different properties and etc.

### Adapted from:

1. [https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ngsi-ld-operations.html](https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ngsi-ld-operations.html)
2. [https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/concise.html](https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/concise.html)

item.name: Provisioning devices to JSON IOT Agent
Add another attribute to special room

request.description:
This request provisions an environmental sensor that records multiple measurements. It not only updates the "urn:ngsi-ld:Device:EnvironmentalSensor001" entity, but also the "urn:ngsi-ld:Room:Room001" entity due to this part of the payload under "static_attributes":

``` json
        {
          "name": "locatedIn",
          "type": "Relationship",
          "value": "urn:ngsi-ld:Room:Room001",
          "link": {
            "attributes": ["temperature"],
            "name": "providedBy",
            "type": "Room"
          }
        },

 ```

This essentially tells the IOT agent to also upsert just the "temperature" attribute to the parent entity (urn:ngsi-ld:Room:Room001). The temperature attribute in the parent entity will also have a "providedBy" relationship pointing to the sensor, hence establishing a two-way relationship.

This example lists all provisioned devices by making a GET request to the `/iot/devices` endpoint.

The response includes all the commands and attributes mappings associated with all devices
This request provisions a robot that can take receive commands.
This request provisions a camera device.

``` json
        {
          "name": "locatedIn",
          "type": "Relationship",
          "value": "urn:ngsi-ld:Room:Room001",

 ```

This essentially tells the IOT agent to also upsert just the "temperature" attribute to the parent entity (urn:ngsi-ld:Room:Room001). The temperature attribute in the parent entity will also have a "providedBy" relationship pointing to the sensor, hence establishing a two-way relationship.

request.description:
This request provisions an environmental sensor that records multiple measurements. It not only updates the "urn:ngsi-ld:Device:EnvironmentalSensor001" entity, but also the "urn:ngsi-ld:Room:Room001" entity due to this part of the payload under "static_attributes":


This essentially tells the IOT agent to also upsert just the "temperature" attribute to the parent entity (urn:ngsi-ld:Room:Room001). The temperature attribute in the parent entity will also have a "providedBy" relationship pointing to the sensor, hence establishing a two-way relationship.

item.name: (1) Check if the IOT Agent is running
Updating values to IOT agents using POST requests

request.description:
This request sends a temperature update to the IOT agent for the EnvironmentalSensor001 device, allowing the IOT agent to send the update to the context broker.

For this endpoint, we require 2 query parameters:

i: The device ID.

k: The device's API key, which has "1234" as the default value. This can be changed in the device provisioning portion.

This request sends a temperature update to the IOT agent for the EnvironmentalSensor001 device, allowing the IOT agent to send the update to the context broker.

For this endpoint, we require 2 query parameters:

i: The device ID.

k: The device's API key, which has "1234" as the default value. This can be changed in the device provisioning portion.
View updates to the related entity in the context broker.
This request sends multiple measures to the IOT agent for the Robot001 device, allowing the IOT agent to send the update to the context broker.
View updates to the related entity in the context broker.

request.description: This request is an example of patching Camera001's static attributes.
View updates to the related entity in the context broker.
This request sends an array of names to the IOT agent for the Camera001 device, allowing the IOT agent to send the update to the context broker.

item.description:
The endpoints in this folder are related to updating/sending measurements of values from the sensor to the IOT agent.

Even though our devices are using MQTT for transport, we can still invoke the HTTP endpoint of the IOT agent meant for receiving measurements from IOT devices.

### Adapted from:

1. [https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/iot-agent-json.html](https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/iot-agent-json.html)
2. [https://fiware-iotagent-json.readthedocs.io/en/latest/usermanual.html](https://fiware-iotagent-json.readthedocs.io/en/latest/usermanual.html)

item.name: Querying Context Broker

request.description: Here, the q parameter is used to find all entities that are located in room 2.

item.name: Find temperature from entities located in room 1

request.description: This request gets all entities located in room 1 that have the "temperature" property. Even though there are also robots and cameras in room 1, those entities are not included as they lack the "temperature" property.

item.name: Find temperature from entities located in room 1 Copy

request.description: This request gets all entities located in room 1 that have the "temperature" property. Even though there are also robots and cameras in room 1, those entities are not included as they lack the "temperature" property.

item.name: Find Humidity from entities located in room 1

request.description: This request gets all entities located in room 1 that have the "temperature" property. Even though there are also robots and cameras in room 1, those entities are not included as they lack the "temperature" property.

item.name: Find all entities of type Room

request.description: Gets all entities of type Room from the context broker. Try executing the query with options enabled to see how the response is compressed.

item.name: Find all entities of type Camera

request.description: Gets all entities of type Camera from the context broker.
Gets all entities of type Device from the context broker.

item.name: Find all entities of type Device

request.description: Gets all entities of type Device from the context broker.
Here, the q parameter is used to find all entities that are located in room 1.
This request gets only 1 entity (Room001). It also uses the concise option to get a more concise response.

item.name: Find all entities of type Robot

request.description: Gets all entities of type Robot from the context broker.

item.description:
The requests in this folder showcases multiple ways to execute queries from a context broker. There are two main ways to query a context broker:

1. By entity ID: `{broker}/ngsi-ld/v1/entities/{entity id}`
2. Using query parameters: `{broker}/ngsi-ld/v1/entities/{query parameters}`
    

The query can be further customised using query parameters:

- `attrs` : Specifies the attributes to be included in the response. Will not return entities that doesn't contain this attribute.
- `options` : Specifies options for the request. Options include:
    - `sysAttrs` : Includes system attributes `createdAt` and `modifiedAt`
    - `keyValues` : Returns the payload in a `key:value` pair format, removing irrelevant properties-of-properties (i.e., modifiedAt) from `Property` or `Relationship` attributes
    - `concise` : Similar to `keyValues`, but also includes properties-of-properties. Ironically, it is less concise than keyValues
- `q` : Perform a filter on entities using operators (i.e., `<`, `>`, `==`)
- `id` : A list of entity IDs
    

### Adapted from:

1. [https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ngsi-ld-operations.html](https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ngsi-ld-operations.html)
2. [https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/concise.html](https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/concise.html)

item.name: Send commands to Robot
Send command from broker Stop robot

item.description:
Do check out the nodered flow equivalent of this section if possible, as this section would require you to send MQTT messages which isn't doable in POSTman. If not:

1. Install mosquitto_pub on your PC
2. After sending a command, execute this line:
    

mosquitto_pub -t /1234/Robot001/cmdexe -h 35.198.213.246 -p 1883 -m '{"x1": "OK"}'

where x1 is the command you executed, and "OK" is the command execution status to pass to the broker.

### Adapted from:

1. [https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/iot-agent-json.html](https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/iot-agent-json.html)
2. [https://fiware-iotagent-json.readthedocs.io/en/latest/usermanual.html](https://fiware-iotagent-json.readthedocs.io/en/latest/usermanual.html)

item.name: Subscriptions
Subscribe to temperature in Room001 falling below 15, retrieve temperature data

request.description:
This query is similar to the previous one, but it uses the `q` parameter to add two conditions:

1. The entity's temperature must be >35
2. The entity must be located in `urn:ngsi-ld:Room:Room001`
    

The `q` parameter supports equality and comparison operators (`>`, `<`, `=` )

The endpoint sends a `POST` request to a google cloud URL, which activates a serverless function that sends a message to this telegram channel ([https://t.me/ngsildsmartupdates](https://t.me/ngsildsmartupdates))
Get all subscriptions that are in the context broker.
Delete a subscription in the context broker using the subscription's ID.

item.name: Subscribe to changes in Temperature from any Device

request.description: This request creates a subscription that subscribes to changes in temperature from all entities of type Device. Essentially, any time a Device's temperature is updated, a POST request would be sent to the endpoint.

item.name: Subscribe to names being spotted by camera

request.description: This subscription sends a notification each time the `names` property is updated. It then sends the `names` and `locatedIn` properties to a google cloud URL, which invokes a command to all Robots that are located in the same room as the camera.

item.description:
Subscriptions provide a way for users to subscribe to updates to context data in the context broker. Once the condition for a subscription is met, the context broker would send requested data to the given endpoint in the subscription through a POST request.

NOTE: The `http` prefix is mandatory for endpoints supplied to the subscription.

### Adapted from:

[https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/subscriptions.html](https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/subscriptions.html)

item.name: Temporal API
Get last 5 updates to temperature from EnvironmentalSensor001

request.description: This request returns the last 5 updates to the `temperature` attribute of EnvironmentalSensor001. As lastN is provided, we do not require a `timerel` parameter.

item.name: Get names of persons previously spotted in Room001

request.description:
This query gets all names spotted by cameras in Room001. It does so by finding all updates that are before the current date and time (generated using Postman's pre-request script function.

The response header would also return a count of 1 (as there is only 1 camera entity in Room001).

This request returns the last 5 updates to each attribute of EnvironmentalSensor001. As lastN is provided, we do not require a `timerel` parameter.

Note that the payload for this request is quite large! Using extra parameters for the temporal API to reduce the size of data transfer is highly encouraged.

This request returns the last 5 updates to each attribute of EnvironmentalSensor001. As lastN is provided, we do not require a `timerel` parameter.

Note that the payload for this request is quite large! Using extra parameters for the temporal API to reduce the size of data transfer is highly encouraged.

item.description:
The context broker API usually only returns the current state of the entities. Hence, all context brokers would have a temporal API (be it as an extra component or built-in) to query for historical data.

## Parameters

### Time Parameters

All temporal queries requires a time parameter. There are two main types of time parameters:

1. lastN : returns the last N updates
2. timerel : `before` or `after` a certain timestamp (in ISO 8601 format. I.e, `2024-03-15T07:55:27.390Z`). The timestamp is provided using `timeAt` .
    

### Other Parameters

- `attrs` : Specifies the attributes to be included in the response. Will not return entities that doesn't contain this attribute.
- `options` : Specifies options for the request. Options include:
    - `sysAttrs` : Includes system attributes `createdAt` and `modifiedAt`
    - `temporalValues`: Each attribute is reduced to a series of tuples - one value and one timestamp for each entry.
    - `count` : Returns the number of entities contained in the response payload through the headers.
- `q` : Perform a filter on entities using operators (i.e., `<`, `>`, `==`)
- `id` : A list of entity IDs that should be included in the query.
    

### Adapted From:

[https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/short-term-history.html](https://ngsi-ld-tutorials.readthedocs.io/en/latest/short-term-history.html)
